page.title: 15IRON WORKS - ASHDOWN FOREST
page.content: A number of sites remain on the fringes of Ashdown Forest which show the intensive activity of the Wealden Iron Industry at its zenith from the late 15th century to the mid-18th century. Many ponds and streams remain in the area, particularly from the time of the first Blast Furnace (with water-powered bellows) at Cotchford and Tilt Hammer at Newbridge Mills. A tributory of the River Medway runs through both sites, and Pippingford Furnace and Forge have been excavated and the Hammer pond, Bay and a Leat for the waterwheel are still present. Newbridge Mill has its hammer pond and leats, at Cotchford and Parrock remains of furnace ponds and bays, and all sites have both cinder and slag in adjacent fields. Pits for iron ore are found throughout the area.
